revisions.rev:
{{Infobox road |country=CAN |type=Hwy |marker_image=[[File:Northern Woods-Water-hwy-Blank.png|100px]] |route=Northern Woods and Water Route |name=Northern Woods and Water Route |map=NWWR.png |length_km=2400 |length_round=0 |length_ref=<ref name="Micro"/> |established= |direction_a=West |direction_b=East |terminus_a= {{jct|province=BC|BC|97}} at [[Dawson Creek|Dawson Creek, British Columbia]] |junction= |terminus_b= [[Perimeter Highway (Winnipeg)|Winnipeg Perimeter Highway-PTH 101]] at [[Winnipeg|Winnipeg, Manitoba]] |rural_municipalities= |cities=[[Dawson Creek|Dawson Creek, British Columbia]]; [[Athabasca, Alberta]]; [[Prince Albert, Saskatchewan]]; [[The Pas, Manitoba]], [[Dauphin, Manitoba|Dauphin]], [[Winnipeg|Winnipeg, Manitoba]] |system={{infobox road/browselinks/CAN|province=BC}}</br>{{infobox road/browselinks/CAN|province=AB}}</br>{{infobox road/browselinks/CAN|province=SK}}</br>{{infobox road/browselinks/CAN|province=MB}} }} The '''Northern Woods and Water Route''' is a {{convert|2400|km|mi|adj=on|spell=Commonwealth|precision=-2| }} route through northern [[British Columbia]], [[Alberta]], [[Saskatchewan]] and [[Manitoba]]. As early as the 1950s community groups came together to establish a northern travel route; this was proposed as the Northern Yellowhead Transportation Route. The Northern Woods and Water Route Association was established in 1974, and encouraged promotion of the route with the promise of an increase in tourist travel.<ref name="Route">{{Cite web | last=Johnston | first=Mark | others=Susan Carr | url=http://mfiqlx.sasktelwebhosting.com/pubs/PAMFCP%20Proposal%20-%20Final.doc | title=Working Proposal Development | work=Prince Albert Model Forest Proposal Submission | accessdate=209-02-11 | format=doc | publisher= | date=October 31, 2006 }} </ref> The route was designated in 1974 and is well signed throughout the connector highways. The route starts at [[Dawson Creek]] at the [[British Columbia Highway 49|British Columbia Spirit River Highway 49]] and ends at [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], running through the northern region of the western provinces.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.planetware.com/canada/northern-woods-and-water-route-cdn-bc-nwwr.htm | title = Northern Woods and Water Route, Canada | date =1995-2009 | publisher = PlanetWare Inc }} </ref> The Northern Woods and Water Route (NWWR) includes connector routes from west to east including [[British Columbia Highway 49]], [[Alberta Highway 49]], [[Alberta Highway 2A|AB Hwy 2A]], [[Alberta Highway 2|AB Hwy 2]], [[Alberta Highway 55|AB Hwy 55]], [[Saskatchewan Highway 55]], [[Saskatchewan Highway 9|SK Hwy 9]], [[Manitoba Provincial Road 283]], [[Manitoba Highway 10]], [[Manitoba Highway 5|MB PTH 5]], [[Manitoba Highway 68|MB PTH 68]], [[Manitoba Highway 6|MB PTH 6]]. The halfway point of the NWWR is approximately at [[Goodsoil, Saskatchewan]]<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.goodsoil.sasktelwebsite.net/ | title = Village of Goodsoil | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | publisher = Plazma Website Design }} </ref>
Fur traders and early settlers utilised the rivers and [[Red River cart]] roads such as ''Long Trail'' until the early 1900s when the railroad and bush planes supplemented travel to this northern boreal transition area. Corduroy roads provided a means for early land vehicles to cross over muskeg and swamp. Horse drawn ploughs filled low areas, settlers hauled gravel and cleared bush for the road ways surveyed along high elevations following lake and river shore lines. Municipalities would grade and gravel roads providing transportation between trading centres. The all weather road arrived alongside of the NWWR association's impetus for a travel and tourism corridor along the northern area of the western provinces. Traffic volume along the route is a major factor to determine highway classification, surface type, and construction upgrades.
==Travel Route== ===British Columbia=== [[File:Dawson Creek Art Gallery.jpg|thumb|upright|left|[[Dawson Creek, British Columbia]] ]] In British Columbia (BC), the route starts within {{convert|17.6|km|mi}} of the BC and Alberta (AB) border in [[Dawson Creek]] at the intersection of [[British Columbia Highway 2|BC Hwy 2]] and [[British Columbia Highway 49|British Columbia Spirit River Highway 49]] west. The northern section of BC Hwy 97 is the [[Alaska Highway]], and the southern sections are the Okanagan Highway, Cariboo Highway, and John Hart Highway from south to north, as well, BC Hwy 2 is known as Tupper Highway. The [[British Columbia Highway 49|British Columbia Spirit River Highway 49]] is the route designated in BC as the NWWR. {{Clear}}
===Alberta=== The NWWR continues east into Alberta on [[Alberta Highway 49|Highway 49]], the Spirit River Highway. Alberta Highway 49 contributes {{convert|19.5|km|mi}} to the NWWR in northwestern Alberta between Donnelly and the Alberta and BC border. The town of [[Spirit River, Alberta|Spirit River's]] population is just over 1,000 and is supported by agriculture and the oil and gas industry creating an annual average daily traffic (AADT) near Spirit River that is about 2,000 vehicles per day vpd.<ref name="ABVolume">{{Cite web | url =http://www.transportation.alberta.ca/2639.htm | title =Traffic Volumes at Points on the Highwayr | work=Alberta Highways 1 to 986 Traffic Volume History (1998-2007) | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | date = 1995 - 2008 | publisher =Government of Alberta }} </ref><ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.townofspiritriver.ca/ | title = Town of Spirit River | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | year = 2009 | publisher = The Town of Spirit River, Alberta, Canada }} </ref>[[File:DSC03269.JPG|thumb|upright|Boreal forest]] To the south is the [[Spirit River (Alberta)|Spirit River]], a tributary of the [[Peace River (Canada)|Peace River]], which is to the north.<ref name="Micro">{{cite map |publisher = Microsoft Corporation Redmond Washington |title = Microsoft Streets and Tips |url = |edition = 2004 |section = |accessdate = 2008-02-10}}</ref> The village of [[Rycroft, Alberta|Rycroft]], "The Hub of the Peace", has a population over 600, and welcomes travellers with their tourism booth in a giant teepee at the junction of Highway 49 and [[Alberta Highway 2|Highway 2]] where the traffic volume increases to about 3,000 vpd.<ref name="ABVolume"/><ref>{{Cite web |last=Connors |first=Ken | url =http://www.discoverthepeacecountry.com/htmlpages/rycroft.html | title = Rycroft, Alberta | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | year = 2009 | publisher = Discover the Peace }} </ref> Wanham Grizzly Bear Prairie Museum is located at the junction of Highway 49 and [[Alberta Highway 773|Highway 773]], where the AADT declines to about 1,000 vpd for the village of [[Wanham, Alberta|Wanham]], which has a population around 600.<ref name="ABVolume"/><ref>{{Cite web |last=Connors |first=Ken | url =http://www.discoverthepeacecountry.com/htmlpages/wanham.html | title = Wanham, Alberta | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | year = 2009 | publisher = Discover the Peace }} </ref> Watino is an [[unincorporated area]] within [[Birch Hills County, Alberta|Birch Hills County]] and the traffic volume declines to between 800 to 900 vpd.<ref name="Statistics">{{Cite web | url =http://www12.statcan.ca/census-recensement/2006/dp-pd/prof/92-591/index.cfm?Lang=E | title = Community Profiles |work= [[Statistics Canada]] |publisher=Government of Canada | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | year = 2006 }} </ref> Bad Heart River is a tributary of the Peace River and flows through Watino. [[Donnelly, Alberta|Donnelly]] is near the junction of Highway 49 and Highway 2 and is also west of Kimiswan Lake.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Connors |first=Ken | url =http://www.discoverthepeacecountry.com/htmlpages/donnelly.html | title =Donnelly, Alberta | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | year = 2009 | publisher = Discover the Peace }} </ref> At Donnelly, traffic volume rises to around 1,800, and the NWWR turns south before arriving at [[Alberta Highway 2A|Highway 2A]].<ref name="ABVolume"/> The next connecting highway along the NWWR is Highway 2. One route would be to follow Highway 2 west from Donnelly to McLennan whenceforth it turns south through Kathleen and intersection Highway 679 until the junction with Highway 2A when the route turns east. This route following Highway 2 through McLennan is {{convert|49.9|km|mi}}. McLennan holds Northern Woods and Water Route caravans every August.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Connors |first=Ken | url =http://www.discoverthepeacecountry.com/htmlpages/mclennan.html | title =McLennan, Alberta | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | year = 2009 | publisher = Discover the Peace }} </ref> The other route would be to follow Highway 2A, a designated alternative route to Highway 2, by turning south at Donnelly staying on Highway 49 until the eastern turn on Highway 2A. This branch from Donnelly till the connection with Highway 2 is {{convert|312.2|km|mi}}. From Donnelly to Athabasca, Alberta, Highway 2 contributes {{convert|56.5|km|mi}} to the NWWR scenic route across the western provinces. [[High Prairie, Alberta|High Prairie]] on the West Prairie River is west of the intersection of [[Alberta Highway 749|Highway 749]] and Highway 2, where traffic jumps to about 7,000 vpd.<ref name="ABVolume"/><ref>{{Cite web |last=Connors |first=Ken | url =http://www.discoverthepeacecountry.com/htmlpages/highprairie.html | title =High Prairie, Alberta | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | year = 2009 | publisher = Discover the Peace }} </ref> Enilda a small hamlet on the East Prairie River is a part of [[Big Lakes, Alberta|Big Lakes]] [[Municipal district]].<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WM5REJ | title =The Signing of Treaty No. 8 - Enilda, Alberta - Alberta Heritage | accessdate = 2009-02-11 |year = 2009 | publisher = Waymarking.com }} </ref> Driftpile is a community on the Driftpile River within the Drift Pile River 150 Indian reserve.<ref name="Statistics"/><ref>{{Cite web | url =http://500nations.com/Alberta_Tribes.asp | title =Alberta First Nations Home | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | date = 1999-2009 | publisher = 500 Inc. }} </ref>[[File:Rycroft Tipi.JPG|thumb|left|upright|[[Rycroft, Alberta]] ]] The Hill and Hollow Campsite and Bay Shore Resort Inc. are located at Faust, which is located on the south shore of [[Lesser Slave Lake]] along Highway 2.<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.northernalberta.worldweb.com/Faust/WheretoStay/Campgrounds/ | title =Alberta First Nations Where to Stay | accessdate = 2009-02-11 |date=1994-2009 | work = Faust Campgrounds | publisher =World Web Technologies Inc. }} </ref> Within the Municipal district of [[Lesser Slave River No. 124, Alberta|Lesser Slave River No. 124]] is the small hamlet of Wagner.<ref name="Statistics"/> Canyon Creek, Widewater and [[Slave Lake, Alberta|Slave Lake]], âThe Jewel of the North", are also on Lesser Slave Lake.<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.slavelake.ca/Rainbow/ | title =Slave Lake | accessdate = 2009-02-11 |year=2004 | work = | publisher = Municipal Township of Slave Lake }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} </ref> [[File:SW Lesser Slave Lake.jpg|thumb|upright|Lesser Slave Lake]]The town of [[Athabasca, Alberta|Athabasca]], "Land of the Whispering Hills", on the [[Athabasca River]] has a population over 2,500 and marks the transition between the NWWR connector routes Highway 2 and [[Alberta Highway 55|Highway 55]]. Traffic volume around Athabasca ranges from 6,000 to 8,000 vpd according to AADT traffic counts at various areas.<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.town.athabasca.ab.ca/ | title =Athabasca, Alberta | accessdate = 2009-02-11 |year=2004 | work = | publisher = Municipal Township of Slave Lake }} </ref><ref name="Mile">{{Cite web | url =http://www.milebymile.com/main/Canada/Alberta/State_55/Canada_Alberta_road_map_travel_guides.html | title =Alberta Road Map RV Travel Guide: #55 Alberta Highway #55 AB/SK Border to City of Athabasca | accessdate = 2009-02-11 |year=2007 | work = | publisher = Mile By Mile Media }} </ref> [[Lac La Biche, Alberta|Lac La Biche]] is located south of [[Lac la Biche (Alberta)|Lac la Biche]] and Beaver Lake on the junction of [[Alberta Highway 36|Highway 36]] and Highway 55, where traffic remains around 7,000 vpd.<ref name="ABVolume"/> [[Sir Winston Churchill Provincial Park]] on Lac la Biche is to the north of the NWWR at this point.<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.laclabicheregion.com/index.php?id=72 | title =Lac La Biche | accessdate = 2009-02-11 |year=2004 |date=Lc La Biche Region | publisher =The Lac La Biche Regional Community Development Corporation }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} </ref> Rich Lake is in [[Lac La Biche County, Alberta|Lac La Biche County]] municipal district, and the traffic volume declines to around 800 vpd.<ref name="ABVolume"/><ref name="Mile"/> La Corey, Beaver Crossing are along Highway 55, which is an asphalt highway and has yearly maintenance.<ref>{{Cite web | url =http:/ /coldlake.infomall.ca/ | title = InfoMall - Cold Lake, Alberta | accessdate = 2009-02-11 |year= 2007 | publisher = Nemtek.net }} </ref>
===Saskatchewan=== Saskatchewan (SK) has six travel corridors of which the Northern Woods and Water Route is the most northerly.<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.worldtravelguide.net/country/243/international_travel/North-America/Saskatchewan.html | title = Getting to Saskatchewan, Airports, Rail, Road, Water, Air Travel | accessdate = 209-02-11 | work = 2009 | publisher =World Travel Guide - Nexus Business Media. A |date= }} </ref> The NWWR begins its journey in north western SK on '''SK Hwy 55''', which crosses {{convert|670.9|km|mi}} of northern Saskatchewan. [[Pierceland, Saskatchewan|Pierceland]], a small [[hamlet]] of the [[Beaver River No. 622, Saskatchewan|Beaver River No. 622]] [[Rural municipality|rural municipality (RM)]], is located at the junction of SK Hwy 55, [[Saskatchewan Highway 950|SK Hwy 950]] north and [[Saskatchewan Highway 21|SK Hwy 21]] south where traffic volume is around 1,000 vpd.<ref name="Statistics"/> The unincorporated area of Peerless, is located at the junction of SK Hwy 55 and [[Saskatchewan Highway 26|SK Hwy 26]] which bears a traffic volume between 600 to 70 vpd.<ref name="HwyVolume">{{Cite web | url =http://www.highways.gov.sk.ca/adx/aspx/adxGetMedia.aspx?DocID=227,81,1,Documents&MediaID=1386&Filename=trafficvolume-2007.pdf | title =Highway Traffic Volume Map trafficvolume-2007.pdf ( 1.5 MB ) | accessdate = 2009-02-08 | year = 2007 | format =Have to rename file as a pdf to open and view | work =Highways and Infrastructure About Highways/Saskatchewan Maps | publisher = Saskatchewan Government }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>[[File:FlottenLake.JPG|thumb|right|Meadow Lake Provincial Park]][[Goodsoil, Saskatchewan|Goodsoil]], the approximate halfway point of the NWWR is located on SK Hwy 26 {{convert|6.2|km|mi}} north of the NWWR enroute to the [[Meadow Lake Provincial Park]]. Rapid View is an unincorporated area of the RM of [[Meadow Lake No. 588, Saskatchewan|Meadow Lake No. 588 RM]].<ref name="Statistics"/> The [[town]] of [[Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan|Meadow Lake]] is located on the north-western shore of Meadow Lake where the AADT is approximately 1,700 to 2,500 vpd.<ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.meadowlake.ca/ | title = InfoMall - Cold Lake, Alberta | accessdate = 2009-02-11 |year= 2009 | publisher = Town of Meadow Lake Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan }}</ref> [[Green Lake, Saskatchewan|Green Lake]], located at the intersection of [[Saskatchewan Highway 55|SK Hwy 55]]] and [[Saskatchewan Highway 155|SK Hwy 155]], is at the northern tip of Green Lake. Traffic volume is considerably higher west of Green River at about 900 vpd dropping to about 350 to the east.<ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.nvgreenlake.ca/ | title =Northern Village | Green Lake | Home | accessdate = 2009-02-11 |year= 2009 | publisher = Northern Village, Green lake, Saskatchewan, CANADA. }}</ref> Between Green Lake and Shellbrook, the NWWR bears south east skirting around the western edge of the Prince Albert National Park. The NWWR follows the eastern shoreline of Cowan Lake until the southern tip at [[Big River, Saskatchewan|Big River]] which is just west of Delaronde Lake, and the highway volume at this point is about 1,000 vpd.<ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.bigriver.ca/ | title =Big River SK and Region |publisher=Big River & District Economic Development Committee/Big River & District Chamber of Commerce. | accessdate = 2009-02-11 |year= 2009 | publisher = Northern Village, Green lake, Saskatchewan, CANADA. }}</ref> [[Big River No. 555, Saskatchewan|Big River No. 555 RM]] provides civic administration to Bodmin.<ref name="Statistics"/> [[Debden, Saskatchewan|Debden]], a [[village]] of about 350, is at the [[Saskatchewan Highway 55|SK Hwy 55]] and [[Saskatchewan Highway 793|SK Hwy 793]] junction where traffic volume is about 850 vpd to the north and around 1,200 vpd to the south of the intersection.<ref name="Statistics"/><ref name="HwyVolume"/> Polwarth, at the SK Hwy 55 and [[Saskatchewan Highway 793|SK Hwy 793 south]] junction, is a hamlet of [[Canwood No. 494, Saskatchewan|Canwood No. 494 RM]]. The village of [[Canwood, Saskatchewan|Canwood]], population of about 350, is located between Polwarth and the town of [[Shellbrook, Saskatchewan|Shellbrook]]. Shellbrook is at the intersection of SK Hwy 55 and [[Saskatchewan Highway 240|SK Hwy 240]] where the AADT increases to about 2,000 vpd.<ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.shellbrook.net/siteengine/activepage.asp | title =iCompass Technologies Inc. | accessdate = 2009-02-11 |year= 2006 | publisher = Shellbrook, SK }}</ref> At Shellbrook, the {{convert|42.5|km|mi}} [[Concurrency (road)|concurrency]] with [[Saskatchewan Highway 3|SK Hwy 3]] begins and the multiplex ends in [[Prince Albert, Saskatchewan|Prince Albert]]. Crutwell, a hamlet of [[Shellbrook No. 493, Saskatchewan|Shellbrook No. 493 RM]], is located south of the NWWR, and north of the [[North Saskatchewan River]]. On the NWWR, at Crutwell, the traffic volume rises to about 3,100.<ref name="HwyVolume"/> At the city of Prince Albert SK Hwy 55 connects with [[Saskatchewan Highway 3|SK Hwy 3]] and [[Saskatchewan Highway 2|SK Hwy 2]]. Traffic volume west of the city is about 4200 vpd, whereas east of the city the AADT drops to approximately 2,090 vpd.<ref name="HwyVolume"/> Prince Albert, located on the North Saskatchewan River, is within {{convert|89.8|km|mi}} of the [[Prince Albert National Park]].<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.citypa.ca/ | title =City of Prince Albert Home | accessdate = 2009-02-11 |year= 2008 | publisher = City of Prince Albert }}</ref>[[File:Princealbert downtown.JPG|thumb|left|upright|[[Prince Albert, Saskatchewan|Prince Albert]] ]] [[Meath Park, Saskatchewan|Meath Park]] is a village of about 200 at the junction of SK Hwy 55, [[Saskatchewan Highway 255|SK Hwy 255]] and [[Saskatchewan Highway 120|SK Hwy 120]] where the traffic volume is heaviest west towards Prince Albert at about 2,000 vpd, and the AADT trickles down to 1,000 vpd east of Meath Park.<ref name="Statistics"/><ref name="HwyVolume"/> The NWWR is located in the [[Flora of Saskatchewan|Boreal transition ecoregion]] which features agricultural fields on the parkland mixed with dense [[taiga]] and sparse population. Over the next {{convert|37.5|km|mi}} there are three small unincorporated areas with populations less than 100; Weirdale is found in the [[Garden River No. 490, Saskatchewan|Garden River No. 490 RM]]; Foxford in [[Paddockwood No. 520, Saskatchewan|Paddockwood No. 520, RM]]; and Shipman of [[Torch River No. 488, Saskatchewan|Torch River No. 488 RM]].<ref name="Statistics"/> At the SK Hwy 55 and SK hwy 255 junction is the village of [[Smeaton, Saskatchewan|Smeaton]], and at the SK Hwy 55 and [[Saskatchewan Highway 691|SK Hwy 691]] junction is the hamlet of Snowden. [[Choiceland, Saskatchewan|Choiceland]] is {{convert|1|km|mi|adj=on}} north of the SK Hwy 55] and the [[Saskatchewan Highway 6|SK Hwy 6]] national highway intersection. Garrick is a part of [[Torch River No. 488, Saskatchewan|Torch River No. 488 RM]] and [[Love, Saskatchewan|Love]], a village of around 60, marks a turn south east for the NWWR. White Fox, a village of about 375 is near the SK Hwy 55 and [[Saskatchewan Highway 35|SK Hwy 35]] intersection where the traffic volume raises to 1,700 vpd.<ref name="HwyVolume"/> At the intersection, the NWWR turns south and a {{convert|12|km|mi}} concurrency begins until the town of [[Nipawin, Saskatchewan|Nipawin]]. [[Nipawin, Saskatchewan|Nipawin]] on the [[Saskatchewan River]], and near both Tobin Lake and Codette Lake is home to the Northern Woods and Water Route Association.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.nipawin.com/index.php?mw=1024 | title = Town of Nipawin | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | work = | publisher = Nipawin.com }} </ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.sasktourism.com/places-to-go/road-trips/northern-woods-and-water-route | title = Northern Woods and Water Route - | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | work = Tourism Saskatchewan | publisher = Government of Saskatchewan }} </ref> West of Nipawin until the [[Saskatchewan Highway 23|SK Hwy 23]] intersection the traffic volume remain around 1,300 vpd and following the intersection to the east the traffic falls to about 400 vpd. There are no communities along the '''[[Saskatchewan Highway 9|SK Hwy 9]]''' route which contributes {{convert|40|km|mi}} to the entire NWWR. At the junction between SK Hwy 55 and Sk hwy 9, the AADT is less than 100 vpd.<ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.milebymile.com/main/Canada/Saskatchewan/State_55_2/Canada_Saskatchewan_road_map_travel_guides.html | title = Manitoba Road Map RV Travel Guide: #68 The Northern Woods and Water Route Manitoba Road Map Travel Guide | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | work = 2007 | publisher = Mile By Mile Media |date= }} </ref>
===Manitoba=== Travel along the NWWR enters Manitoba via the '''[[Manitoba Provincial Road 283|MB PR 283 west]]''' ending at [[The Pas, Manitoba|The Pas]], a town of about 5,500 where the AADT increases to 980 vpd.<ref name="MBVolume">{{Cite web | url =http://umtig.mgmt.umanitoba.ca/ | title =Manitoba Highway Traffic Information System (MHTIS) | work=2007 Traffic Report | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | date = 1995 - 2008 | publisher =University of Manitoba Transport Information Group }} </ref> MB PR 283 provides {{convert|38.6|km|mi}} of the NWWR where the economy has been supported by the fur trade, trapping, mining, fishing, logging and agricultural industries.<ref name="pas"/>{{rp|35|58}} The Pas, which has not yet incorporated as a city (requisite population of 5,000), is located south of the Saskatchewan River and south of the [[Clearwater Provincial Park]] and Cormorant Provincial Forest.<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.thepasarea.com/ | title = The Pas Area | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | work = 2006 - 2009 | publisher = Township of The Pas |date= }} </ref>[[Image:Duck Mountain Park.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Duck Mountain Provincial Park (Manitoba)|Duck Mountain Provincial Park]] ]] Travel along the NWWR out of The Pas continues south along '''[[Manitoba Highway 10|MB PTH 10]]''' and continues on MB PTH 10 for {{convert|411.6|km|mi}}. Pasquia River flows through The Pas, and travels west of the NWWR until it turns west to Saskatchewan near Westray. Freshford and Westray are both within the [[Kelsey, Manitoba|Kelsey RM]].<ref name="Statistics"/> Overflowing River, a small community with less than 100 residents is a part of the Unorganized Division No. 21. Overflowing River community is located on the Overflowing River and at the north-west tip of Dawson Bay of [[Lake Winnipegosis]] whereas Makefing is east of the Porcupine Provincial Forest. Bellsite, Novra, and [[Birch River, Manitoba|Birch River]] are all small unorganised areas of [[Mountain, Manitoba|Mountain (North) RM]] located west of Swan Lake. [[Bowsman, Manitoba|Bowsman]] with a population of over 300, is the next largest village along the NWWR after The Pas.<ref name="Statistics"/><ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.communityprofiles.mb.ca/cgi-bin/csd/index.cgi?id=4620052 | title = Manitoba Community Profiles - Community Profile:Village of Bowsman | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | work = 2006 - 2009 | publisher = Government of Manitoba |date= }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} </ref>[[File:Moosecrossing.JPG|thumb|left|upright|Moose Crossing sign on [[Manitoba Highway 10|MB PTH 10]] ]] [[Swan River, Manitoba|Swan River]], in the Swan River valley, is between the Duck Mountains and Porcupine Mountains. North of Swan River, the AADT increases to about 2,000 vpd and the NWWR changes course at Swan River and bears east.<ref name="MBVolume"/><ref>{{Cite web |last=Solonyka |first=Ed | url =http://swanrivermanitoba.ca/ | title = Town of Swan River | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | work = 1999 - 2006 | publisher = emediawebsites.com |date= }} </ref> [[Minitonas, Manitoba|Minitonas]] is on the Favel River and at the junction of MB PTH 10 and [[Manitoba Provincial Road 366|MB PR 366 south]]. West of MB PTH 10 and [[Manitoba Provincial Road 268|MB PR 268 north]] intersection, traffic volume is over 1,100 vpd, and east of MB PR 268 traffic declines to about 750 vpd.<ref name="MBVolume"/> Renwer is a small community found in the [[Minitonas, Manitoba (rural municipality)|Minitonas RM]]. The MB PTH 10 and [[Manitoba Highway 20|MB PTH 20]] intersection is located at the hamlet of Cowan in [[Mountain, Manitoba|Mountain (South) RM]] and here the NWWR resumes its route south. Sclater and Pine River two places with populations less than 100 are also found in [[Mountain, Manitoba|Mountain (South) RM]]. The NWWR is to the east of [[Duck Mountain Provincial Park (Manitoba)|Duck Mountain Provincial Park]] and Duck Mountain Provincial Forest and west of Lake Winnipegosis. Garland is located at the intersection of [[Manitoba Provincial Road 489|MB PR 489 east]], [[Manitoba Provincial Road 367|MB PR 367 west]], MB PTH 10A and MB PTH 10. Ethelbert, a small hamlet of the [[Ethelbert, Manitoba (rural municipality)|Ethelbert RM]], is located at the intersection of [[Manitoba Provincial Road 269|MB PR 269 west]], [[Manitoba Provincial Road 274|MB PR 274 south]] and MB PTH 10. The AADT along MB PTH 10 declines to about 680 vpd near this intersection.<ref name="MBVolume"/>[[File:Bison herd - Lake Audy - Riding Mountain National Park.JPG|thumb|upright|[[Riding Mountain National Park]] ]] Ashville is located north of the MB PTH 10 and [[Manitoba Highway 5|MB PTH 5]] junction in this parkland area of [[Gilbert Plains, Manitoba (rural municipality)|Gilbert Plains, RM]]. The NWWR continues east along the '''[[Manitoba Highway 5|MB PTH 5]]''', using this connector route for a total of {{convert|40|km|mi}}.<ref name="Statistics"/> The [[city]] of [[Dauphin, Manitoba|Dauphin]] is located north of [[Riding Mountain National Park]] and south of [[Dauphin Lake]]. Near this city, the traffic volume jumps to 2,750 vpd, with the heaviest day of the week being Friday, and the highest volume occurring between April and October during daylight hours.<ref name="MBVolume"/><ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.dauphin.ca/ | title =Dauphin | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | work =Dauphin Economic Development | publisher = |date=2003-2005 }} </ref> [[Ochre River, Manitoba|Ochre River]] is located at the junction of MB PTH 10 and [[Manitoba Provincial Road 582|MB PR 582]] south of [[Rainbow Beach Provincial Park]].<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.communityprofiles.mb.ca/cgi-bin/csd/index.cgi?id=4617045 | title =Ochre River. | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | work =R.M. of Ochre River Community Profile: | publisher = Government of Manitoba |date= }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} </ref> [[Ste. Rose du Lac, Manitoba|Ste. Rose du Lac]], a town of about 1,000, is at the intersection of [[Manitoba Highway 5|MB PTH 5]], [[Manitoba Highway 68|MB PTH 68]] and [[Manitoba Provincial Road 276|MB PR 276]]. Near this intersection, the traffic volume declines to around 1,800 vpd.<ref name="MBVolume"/> At Ste. Rose du Lac, cattle capital of Manitoba, the NWWR continues west on '''[[Manitoba Highway 68|MB PTH 68]]''' and this connector highway will carry the NWWR for {{convert|128.2|km|mi}}.<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.town.sterosedulac.mb.ca/ | title =Ochre River. | accessdate = 2009-02-11 | work =Town of Ste Rose du Lac | publisher = Government of Manitoba |date= }} </ref> Shergrove is located close to the turn off north from the easterly direction of [[Manitoba Highway 68|MB PTH 68]]. Ebb and Flow Lake is east of Eddystone which is part of [[Alonsa, Manitoba (rural municipality)|Alonsa RM]]. Wapah, another small community, is between Ebb and Flow Lake, and Lake Manitoba. [[Siglunes, Manitoba|Siglunes RM]] administrates civic affairs for Vogar which is south of Dog Lake. At Vogar the NWWR returns to an east direction. At Mulvihill the NWWR turns south and the {{convert|10.4|km|mi}} concurrency between MB PTH 68 and [[Manitoba Highway 6|MB PTH 6]] begins.[[File:Deep Lake - Riding Mountain National Park.JPG|left|thumb|upright|[[Riding Mountain National Park]] ]] At Eriksdale, MB PTH 68 turns east and the concurrency between MB PTH 68 and [[Manitoba Highway 6|MB PTH 6]] ends, however the NWWR continues on '''MB PTH 6''' in a southerly direction for the final {{convert|135.6|km|mi}} leg of the travel corridor. Deerhorn is found in the [[Eriksdale, Manitoba|Eriksdale, RM]]. The NWWR continues south along PTH 6 and parallel to the eastern shores of [[Lake Manitoba]]. Lundar and Clarkleigh are both located in [[Coldwell, Manitoba|Coldwell, RM]]. The unincorporated area of Lundar is located at the intersection of [[Manitoba Provincial Road 418|MB PR 418]] east, PTH 6, and [[Manitoba Provincial Road 419|MB PR 419]]. MB PR 419 west provides access to the [[Lundar Beach Provincial Park]]. The hamlet of Clarkleigh is located at the intersection of MB PTH 6, and [[Manitoba Provincial Road 229|MB PR 229 east]]. Oakpoint is at the intersection of MB PTH 6, and MB PR 419, and St. Laurent is at MB PTH 6 and [[Manitoba Provincial Road 415|MB PR 415]].[[File:Winnipeg skyline north side.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Winnipeg, Manitoba]] ]] The hamlet of Lake Francis is located west of West Shoal Lake. Both Woodlands and Warren are unincorporated areas with small populations below 100 of [[Woodlands, Manitoba|Woodlands RM]]. The AADT along the NWWR increases to over 2,500 vpd near these communities.<ref name="MBVolume"/> Woodlands is at thei intersection of PTH 6 and [[Manitoba Provincial Road 518|MB PR 518]] and Warren is located at [[Manitoba Highway 67|MB PTH 67]] and MB PTH 6. Grosse Isle is the last hamlet along NWWR before arriving at [[Perimeter Highway (Winnipeg)|Perimeter Highway, the PTH 101]] around [[Winnipeg]], the ending terminus of the NWWR.<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.milebymile.com/main/Canada/Manitoba/Parkway_68/Canada_Manitoba_road_map_travel_guides.html | title = Manitoba Road Map RV Travel Guide: #68 The Northern Woods and Water Route Manitoba Road Map Travel Guide | accessdate = 209-02-11 | work = 2007 | publisher = Mile By Mile Media |date= }} </ref><ref name="AlaskaAliner">{{Cite web | url =http://www.alinerclub.org/alaskatrip_pierre.htm | title = New Page 0 |work=Alaska the long way.... 2003 | accessdate = 209-02-11 | work = 2002-2003 | publisher = Aliner Owners Club |date= }} </ref>
==History== [[File:Borealforest.jpg|thumb|upright|Boreal forest]] The ''Long Trail'' followed the Peace River {{convert|100|mi|km}}530 across northern AB. As the flow of traffic increased due to the fur trade industry along the Long Trail, stopping places developed providing rest and food for travelers. In 1923, the three routes out of Lac La Biche were to the west, which corresponds to the route of AB Hwy 55 along the south shores of Lesser Slave Lake. Edmonton or Saddle Lake trail departed to the south, which would be the initial stages of AB Hwy 55 out of Lac La Biche.<ref name="Spirit"/> Heart Lake trail traveled northeast from Lac La Biche, which would form a base for secondary AB Hwy 858. Work was done on the Athabaska Trail to make it passable for motor traffic as many roads had been graded.<ref>{{Cite book | last =Hotchkiss | first = C.F. | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Lac la Biche District Alberta: a guide for intending settlers : compiled information obtained on land classification surveys. | work = Our Roots Nos Racines | publisher = University of Calgary, UniversitÃ© Laval | year =1923 | url = http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=863091 | format = Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines | doi = |pages=35â42 | accessdate = 2009-02-18}}</ref> Before stopping places developed, caches were set up at stopping points along the way.<ref name="Spirit"/> Before the arrival of rails the waterways such as the Lesser Slave Lake near Athabasca, Alberta and the Saskatchewan River near Prince Albert were traversed by long boat, canoe, and steamship.<ref name="Nipawin">{{Cite book | last = Nipawin Historical Society | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Bridging the Years: Nipawin Saskatchewan | work = Our Roots Nos Racines | publisher = University of Calgary, UniversitÃ© Laval | year =2006 | url = http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=3712710 | format = Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines | doi = |pages=78â84 | accessdate = 2009-02-18}}</ref> The rail did not reach the northern areas until the early twentieth century due to the geological hurdles of mountains, muskeg, swamp, boreal forest, and river systems to traverse.<ref name="Spirit">{{Cite book | last = Spirit River History Book Committee | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Chepi sepe:Spirit River: the land, the people | work = Our Roots Nos Racines | publisher = University of Calgary, UniversitÃ© Laval | year =2006 | url = http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=3712710 | format = Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines | doi = |pages=35â42 | accessdate = 2009-02-18}}</ref> A huge flood in 1899 near [[The Pas, Manitoba|The Pas]] left no ground to walk upon, yet the railway track construction work began in 1906, with more continuing in 1911.<ref name="pas"/> In 1928, the [[Canadian Pacific Railway|Canadian Pacific Railway (CPR)]] surveyed their line across the Saskatchewan River near Prince Albert, and contractors started work on the bridge. The upper deck served the train, and the lower deck was built for highway traffic opening for vehicles in 1932.<ref name="Nipawin"/> In 1929, travel was overland on trails, and rivers were forded in many places.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Lac La Biche Heritage Society | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Lac La Biche: yesterday and today | work = Our Roots Nos Racines | publisher = University of Calgary, UniversitÃ© Laval | year =1971 | url = http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=3610704 | format = Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines | doi = |pages=38 | accessdate = 2009-02-18}}</ref>
As early as 1896 oil wells were drilled at Athabasca supplementing the rich soils and grain growing economy. There was a rush of settlers to the area in the early 1900s, at this time transportation for goods was freighted on Lesser Slave Lake to connecting river routes or via early rail lines overland.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Oppen | first = William A | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Athabasca Landing | work = Our Roots Nos Racines | publisher = University of Calgary, UniversitÃ© Laval | year =1971 | url = http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=3619248 | format = Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines | doi = |pages=73â75 | accessdate = 2009-02-18}}</ref> Fortune seekers during the gold rush of 1896 traveled north through Edmonton or took the rail as far north as Prince Albert. The westerly route proceeded from Prince Albert to Green Lake, and from there to the ''Long Trail'' by following the Beaver River to the Churchill River, Athabaska, Slave and Mackenzie rivers until bearing north following the rivers of the Yukon to Dawson City.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Abrams | first = Gary William DAvid | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Prince Albert: the first century, 1866-1966 | work = Our Roots Nos Racines | publisher = University of Calgary, UniversitÃ© Laval | year =1971 | url = http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=545759 | format = Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines | doi = |pages=109â110 | accessdate = 2009-02-18}}</ref>
The first garage to service McLaughlin cars opened in High River as early as 1909. In 1912 travelers could stop here at a filling station for their automobiles. This same year the speed limit through town was not over ten miles per hour (16 km/h) and not over five miles per hour (8 km/h) upon approaching another horse or pedestrian, the fine was not more than [[Canadian dollar|C$]]50.00.<ref group="nb">C$50,00 from 1912 is equivalent to ${{Formatprice|{{Inflation|US|50|1912|r=-2}}}} in present day terms.</ref>{{Inflation-fn|US}}<ref name="Justiceplus">{{Cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = A History of the Canadian Dollar | work = Le Site De Justiceplus - The Justiceplus Site | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.justiceplus.org/thedollar.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2008-12-28}} Rationale to use US currency converson template. $10 Canadian was equivalent to US$10 gold eagle 1851-1867. 1879-1914 the US and Canadian dollar traded again at par.</ref><ref name="Bank">{{Cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = The Canadian Dollar under the Gold Standard (1854-1914) | work =Bank of Canada | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.bankofcanada.ca/en/dollar_book/1854-1914.pdf | format = pdf | accessdate = 2008-12-28}} Rationale to use US currency converson template. Bank of Canada notes that from 1854-1914 the US and Canadian dollar traded at par.</ref> <ref>{{Cite book | last = originally pbulished McAra Presses | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Spitzee Days | work = Our Roots Nos Racines | publisher = University of Calgary, UniversitÃ© Laval | year =1971 | url = http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=4388 | format = Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines | doi = |pages=118 | accessdate = 2009-02-18}}</ref> The Pas, Manitoba saw its first car arrive in 1916, yet it had been active with fur trading posts and explorers in the area since 1741.
Settlers would not only haul gravel for the new roadways, but they also cleared brush for the road allowance.<ref>{{Cite book | last =Ewanchuk | first = M | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Pioneer Settlers: Ukrainians in the Dauphin Area, 1896 - 1926 | work = Our Roots Nos Racines | publisher = University of Calgary, UniversitÃ© Laval | year =1988 | url = http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=2614 | format = Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines | doi = |pages=160 | accessdate = 2009-02-18}}</ref> Early roads did not follow the road allowances of the Dominion Land Survey, but rather kept to higher ground, however due to the nature of the Boreal transition ecoregion, muskegs and swamps still needed to be traversed. The first pioneers filled these watery areas with branches and brush and proceeded along their trip. Later corduroy roads were built across these areas were traffic got mired in the mud. A corduroy road consisted of logs laid across the road as a rail tie is across the rail line, however the logs were placed one against another and mud filled between the logs for a smoother surface. One log provided about {{convert|6|in|cm}} of roadway, so only the worst areas were constructed in this fashion.<ref>{{Cite book | last=Griffith |first=David | coauthors = | title =Notes on the Goodridge and area | work = Our Roots Nos Racines | publisher = University of Calgary, UniversitÃ© Laval | year =1967 online publication 2006 | url = http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=3538426 | format = Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines | doi = |Pages= | accessdate = 2009-02-18}}</ref>
Debden, Saskatchewan had a horse and caboose taxi for settlers as early as 1912 providing regular trips to Prince Albert and taking children to school. In 1945, the taxi service was provided by automobile.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Debden History Book Association | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Memories to Stay, 1912-1985: History of Debden and area | work = Our Roots Nos Racines | publisher = University of Calgary, UniversitÃ© Laval | year =1985 | url = http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=4388 | format = Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines | doi = |pages=39 | accessdate = 2009-02-18}}</ref> Bush planes arrived in the 1920s to the northern bus areas providing communication in an era where travel was limited when the snow fell, or the water froze.<ref name="pas">{{Cite book | last = The Pas Manitoba | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Fiftieth Anniversary, 1912 - 1962, The Pas, Manitoba, Canada: golden jubilee celbrations, August 24, 25, 26, 1962 | work = Our Roots Nos Racines | publisher = University of Calgary, UniversitÃ© Laval | year =1971 | url = http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=4062867 | format = Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines | doi = |pages=17 | accessdate = 2009-02-18}}</ref> In 1968, High Prairie was looking forward to hard surface construction for AB Hwy 2 which would supplement the economic trading base with tourism.<ref name="High">{{Cite book | last = Farm Women's Union of Alberta Centennial Book Committee | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Pioneers who Blazed the Trail: a history of High Prairie and district (The Foundations and its Builders) | work = Our Roots Nos Racines | publisher = University of Calgary, UniversitÃ© Laval | year =1968 | url = http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=4388 | format = Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines | doi = |pages=317 | accessdate = 2009-02-18}}</ref> A new bridge across the Saskatchewan River at Prince Albert was erected in 1974, and caused re-routing of the highway by one and a half miles (2.4 km).<ref name="Nipawin"/> Community groups came together as early as the 1950s to establish a northern travel route.
The early name proposed for these travel corridor was the Northern Yellowhead Transportation Route. The Northern Woods and Water Route Association was established in 1974, their further promotion of the route was to increase tourist travel.<ref name="Route"/> George R. Stephenson (1916â2003), of [[McLennan, Alberta|McLennan]] was one of the first facilitators to organise the Northern Woods and Water Route across Western Canada in 1974.<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.southpeacenews.com/obituaries/georgerstephenson.html | title = George R. Stephenson, 1916-2003 |work=South Peace News Obituary | accessdate = 209-02-11 | publisher = |date= 1999-2003 }} </ref> Henry Andres was chairman of the Northern Woods and Water Association for eight years wherein the association worked on placing NWWR signs both on provincial highways and maps. Brochures promoting tourism were printed, and the association sponsored more than five cavalcades where wagons would traverse the route between Winnipeg and Dawson Creek promoting tourism and the creation of the travel corridor. On August 21, 1975, one of these Northern Woods and Water Cavalcades stopped at Nipawin Regional Park and toured Nipawin.<ref name="Nipawin"/><ref name="Nipawin"/>{{rp|304}}
Current engineering concerns would be to determine maintenance of the current travel corridor and construction upgrades. The route does contain a variety of road surfaces ranging from [[asphalt concrete]], [[Road surface#Thin membrane surface|thin membrane surface (TMS)]], [[Road surface#Granular|granular pavements]] and [[gravel road|gravel highway]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gerbrandt |first=Ron |other=Tim Makahoniuk, Cathy Lynn Borbely, Curtis Berthelot | title = Guidelines must be followed strictly - No exceptions | work = Effect of Cold-[in-place recycling on the Heavyweight Trucking Industry | publisher =6th International Conference on Heavy Vehicle Weights and Dimension Proceedings | year = 2000 | url =http://engrwww.usask.ca/entropy/tc/publications/pdf/cirheavyweighttruckingpostedfinalpdf.pdf | format = | doi = | accessdate =2009-01-25 }} </ref> Insight into current surface texture, traffic volume, traffic speed, percentage of loaded trucks, climate variations, construction costs and time as well as available materials will affect upgrade procedures.<ref>{{Cite book |last= Gransberg |first=Douglas D. |firstn= David M. B. ,lastn=James |others=National Cooperative Highway |title=Chip Seal Best Practices |url=http://books.google.ca/books?id=gTCHtuGENwQC&dq=Chip+Seal+Best+Practices&printsec=frontcover&source=bl&ots=aasxrb4p_f&sig=-Mv9yWOzDTOBfqwazscYcMQInz8&hl=en&ei=I6uhSa_ZEozaNP3WuOIL&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result#PPA15,M1 |format=Digitised online by Google books |accessdate=2009-02-25 |year=2005 |publisher=Transportation Research Board |isbn=0309097444, 9780309097444 |pages=13â20 }} </ref> The entire route is paved except for a Class 4 gravel highway segment between [[Nipawin, Saskatchewan|Nipawin]] and the Manitoba border.<ref name="Route"/><ref name="Surface type">{{Cite web | url =http://www.highways.gov.sk.ca/adx/aspx/adxGetMedia.aspx?DocID=227,81,1,Documents&MediaID=1461&Filename=surface.pdf | title =2007-08 Saskatchewan Highway Surface Type surface.pdf (302 KB) | year = 2007 | format =Have to rename file as a pdf to open and view | work =Highways and Infrastructure About Highways/Saskatchewan Maps | publisher = Saskatchewan Government }}</ref> Here the traffic volume declines to 80 and 85 vpd and two checkpoints near the Manitoba border.<ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref name="Class">{{Cite web | url = http://www.highways.gov.sk.ca/adx/aspx/adxGetMedia.aspx?DocID=227,81,1,Documents&MediaID=1500&Filename=2007-08+Road+Classification.pdf | title = 2007-08 Road Classification Map 2007-08 Road Classification.pdf (424.5 KB) | accessdate = 2009-02-08 | year = 2007 | format =Have to rename file as a pdf to open and view | work =Highways and Infrastructure About Highways/Saskatchewan Maps | publisher = Saskatchewan Government }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
